title: 106_s660
content: The text chunk "SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE; FINDINGS." is a condensed summary of the section title and findings. The Act may be cited as the "Medicare Medical Nutrition Therapy Act of 1999". Congress finds that medical nutrition therapy is cost-effective in treating various diseases in the elderly, leading to reduced healthcare costs and hospitalizations. A study by The Lewin Group suggests that coverage of medical nutrition therapy under Medicare would result in savings exceeding costs after the third year. The Medicare Medical Nutrition Therapy Act of 1999 aims to provide coverage for medical nutrition therapy for all Medicare beneficiaries, with projected savings in following years. The Agency for Health Care Policy and Research emphasizes the importance of nutrition in preventing and treating pressure ulcers, which cost the healthcare system billions annually. Nearly 17 million patients are treated each year for malnutrition-related illnesses or injuries, highlighting the need for accessible medical nutrition therapy. Access to low-tech treatment is denied, leading to more complications and higher treatment costs. SEC. 2. MEDICARE COVERAGE OF MEDICAL NUTRITION THERAPY SERVICES. Amends the Social Security Act to include coverage for medical nutrition therapy services. The term 'medical nutrition therapy services' refers to nutritional diagnostic, therapy, and counseling services provided by a registered dietitian or nutrition professional with a referral from a physician. A registered dietitian or nutrition professional is an individual with a degree in nutrition or dietetics and supervised experience. The text discusses the requirements for individuals to provide medical nutrition therapy services, including completing supervised practice hours and obtaining licensure or certification. Payment regulations under Section 1833(a)(1) of the Act are also amended. The text discusses amendments to payment regulations under Section 1833(a)(1) of the Act, specifically regarding medical nutrition therapy services. The amendments include changes to the amount paid for these services, with an effective date of January 1, 2000.
